input2: She is with no significant medical history with 4 hours of back pain radiating to the abdomen transfers. Patient reports she has been feeling her usual state of health until around 4pm, had acute onset of severe back pain that started at her upper back and radiated around her abdomen and at one point even down to her right leg and to the right shoulder. She also had significant bloating with the pain, mild nausea and tried to pass flatus and bowel movement without success. Her pain continued to be migratory around the abdomen and she presented to where she had normal vitals, SBP 120s and labs notable for WBC of 14.7 (LFTs, lipase normal, trop neg). She underwent CTA abd/pelvis which showed a descending aortic dissection originating distal to the takeoff of the subclavian artery extending down just past the iliac bifurcation to R common iliac artery with the celiac actery, SMA and renal arteries perfused by the true lumen and by the false lumen. She was given pain medication and transferred for further management. Upon transfer, patient's SBPs were in 110-120s, labs notable for WBC 22.4. She reports that her pain is currently much improved however focal in her upper back and her bloating has subsided.

Imaging:
CTA abd/pelvis, WETREAD ONLY):
descending aortic dissection originating distal to the takeoff of the subclavian artery extending down just past the iliacbifurcation to R common iliac artery with the celiac actery, SMA and renal arteries perfused by the true lumen and by the false lumen.

ECHO ___
PRE-BYPASS: The left atrium is mildly dilated. No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of the left atrium/left atrial appendage or the body of the right atrium/right atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal for the patient's body size. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. There are simple atheroma in the ascending aorta. There are focal calcifications in the aortic arch. A mobile density is seen in the descending aorta consistent with an intimal flap/aortic dissection. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. There is no pericardial effusion.
